tossups.question: One senator from this state highlighted wasteful government spending by citing a study where NIH workers made repeated visits to a Peruvian brothel in the interest of “accuracy”; that senator awarded the Golden Fleece Award to the most outrageous spending. Another senator from this state beat up Drew Pearson during a party at the Sulgrave Club. Charles van Hise worked with a senator from this state to develop its namesake (*) “Idea.” That senator and Montana’s Burton Wheeler ran on the 1924 Progressive Party ticket. At a speech in Wheeling, a senator from this state said he had a list of “enemies from within”, prompting criticism from Edward R. Murrow. For 10 points, name this state, home to senators Robert La Follette and Joseph McCarthy.
tossups.answer: Wisconsin (the first senator is William Proxmire)

tossups.question: A story by this author about a months-long traffic jam served as the inspiration for Jean-Luc Godard’s film Week End. The Kid is killed by a tiger that wanders freely around the grounds in this author’s story “Bestiary.”  The narrator of a story by this author is working as a translator when he discovers that a blonde woman was (*) propositioning a teenage boy on behalf of a man waiting in a car. In another story by this author, a visitor to the Jardin des Plantes in Paris is fascinated by, and eventually turns into, the title amphibian. A photographer discovers a dead body in the film adaptation of a story by this author directed by Michelangelo Antonioni. For 10 points, name this Argentinian author of “Axolotl,” “Blow-Up,” and the novel Hopscotch.
tossups.answer: Julio Cortázar [or Julio Florencio Cortázar]

tossups.question: Note to players: give either the group of instruments or the name of the ensemble. After recording a work for this ensemble and orchestra, Karajan eschewed a final take in favor of a photograph with the soloists. That work for this ensemble and orchestra was premiered at the Vienna “Augarten” concerts and ends with a Rondo alla Polacca finale. The largo second movement of a piece for this ensemble may have been based on a “Witches’ Chorus” for the unfinished opera Macbeth. The lengthy tremolos and chromaticism of that piece for this ensemble led Czerny to coin its (*) spooky nickname. These instruments are the soloists in Beethoven’s only concerto for multiple soloists, and Beethoven composed works nicknamed Ghost and Archduke for this group of instruments. For 10 points, Beethoven’s Triple Concerto was written for what group of instruments that comprise a piano trio?
tossups.answer: violin, cello, and piano [accept piano trio before mention; prompt on trio; DO NOT accept or prompt on a partial answers involving instruments]

tossups.question: Thin layers of this element surround molecular impurities in a type of van der Waals solid whose behavior resembles that of a quantum aerogel. Observations of ground-state vacancies in solids of this element led to the discovery that its atoms adopt an anti-ferromagnetic ordering. Since one form of this element possesses a negative heat of solidification, isentropic compression will cause that form of this element to undergo (*) Pomeranchuk cooling. Rotons are a quasiparticle posited to explain anomalies in specific heat measurements of this element by Lev Landau. Rollin films form when one form of this element exhibits a “creeping” phenomenon due to the Onnes effect. For 10 points, name this element that exhibits superfluidity below the lambda point.
tossups.answer: helium [or He; accept impurity-helium solids; helium-2 or helium-3 or helium-4]

tossups.question: Ruth Barcan Marcus argued that a consistent set of these things could only exist if there was a possible world where the entire set was obeyable. R.M. Hare argued that these things possess universalizability and prescriptivity in a book titled for the Language of these things. A paper titled for these things argues that secular approaches to them lack grounding and coined the term "consequentialism." That paper by (*) G.E.M. Anscombe is titled for the modern philosophy of these things. Bernard Williams introduced a situation that results when agents are assigned blame for things that they had no control over, which he termed these things' "luck." For 10 points, name these things, the guiding principles for determining right and wrong.
tossups.answer: morals [accept ethics; accept moral systems or similar answers]

tossups.question: Teledyne’s Odom MB2 is one example of an MBES device used to study this structure. Nepheloid sediment is a common challenge to the accurate measurement of this structure. Measurements of this structure are combined with data from digital elevation models to create global relief models. LADS and SHOALS are two systems for high-density airborne (*) laser measurement of this structure. Measurements of this structure collected using LIDAR technology have replaced traditional methods for studying this structure, which constructed “soundings” and “isobaths” from data collected using cables and bouys. For 10 points, name this structure whose mapping is the subject of bathymetry and whose lowest point is in the Marianas trench.
tossups.answer: ocean floor [or seafloor; accept equivalents like “the bottom of the ocean/sea”]

tossups.question: Camila O’Gorman was executed by a dictator of this country for having sex with a Catholic priest. A secret police in this country founded by that dictator’s wife, Doña Encarnacion, was named “ear of corn.” Julio Roca, a member of this country’s Generation of ‘80, exterminated most of this country’s native population. Justo José de Urquiza took over this country after defeating its previous leader at (*) Caseros. Bartolomé Mitre led this country during the War of the Triple Alliance, during which it allied with Brazil and Uruguay. This country’s porteños were ruled over by the “Restorer of Laws”, Juan Manuel de Rosas. For 10 points, name this country where gauchos settled Patagonia.
tossups.answer: Argentina

tossups.question: Bob Avian directed this musical’s 2006 revival, which was headlined by Chicago star Charlotte d’Amboise in the role that won Donna McKechnie a Tony in the original production. In one scene from this musical, the tone-deaf Kristine laments her poor singing ability while her husband Al interrupts her to finish each line in proper tune. This musical’s first montage scene features multiple characters sharing memories of (*) childhood romances in the song “Hello Twelve, Hello Thirteen, Hello Love”. The lines “step, kick, kick, leap, kick, touch” open this musical’s best-known song, in which each performer expresses their desire to be selected, “I Hope I Get It”. For 10 points, name this Marvin Hamlisch scored musical about casting the title group of dancers.
tossups.answer: A Chorus Line

tossups.question: In Jainism, Gunasthana describes the 14 stages a human must undergo to be dissociated from this concept. The Jain concept of asrava refers to the body and mind's propensity to force the soul to engage with this concept. This concept accounts for two parts of the human predicament, and this concept is attracted to fields created by the mind as a form of "dirt." In the Bhagavati (*) Aradhana, this concept is considered the most powerful force in the universe, and all tirthankaras have to bear the weight of this concept from humanity. In Buddhism, this concept drives samsara, or the cycle of reincarnation. For 10 points, name this concept from South Asian religions that states past actions affect future lives.
tossups.answer: karma [accept karmayoga]

tossups.question: In one story from this country, an opera singer who lost her voice in a fire adopts different disguises. In another story from this country, Death spares the life of the emperor of China after hearing a nightingale’s song. The Countess Calypso and Miss Nat-og-Dag are among the characters in a story from this country who tell tales while waiting for a flood to pass. “The Dreamers” and “The (*) Deluge at Norderney” are stories from this country included in Seven Gothic Tales. An author from this country wrote about a girl who is carried to heaven by her grandmother after freezing to death. The Sea Witch gives the title character legs to walk on land in a story that inspired a sculpture in its capital. For 10 points, name this home country of the author of “The Little Match Girl” and “The Little Mermaid,” Hans Christian Andersen.
tossups.answer: Denmark [accept word forms like Danish literature]

tossups.question: In one model, the Z=2 case of the Hamiltonian describing these species has eigenvalues equal to “minus E over quantity (n plus r)-squared”. Effects of these species define the potential energy surface for nuclear movement under the Born-Oppenheimer approximation. Two of the four fundamental constants in atomic units are characteristic of these species. (*) Wavefunctions describing these species must be antisymmetric under exchange interactions. Measurements of the speed and period of these species give their time spent in the 1st Bohr orbit. Abbreviations of K, L, and M describe the different “shells” containing these species, whose outermost occupied example is referred to as “valence”. For 10 points, name these species shared in chemical bonds.
tossups.answer: electron(s) [accept valence electron(s), accept paired or unpaired electrons accept lone pair accept (free) radicals; prompt on Fermions; prompt on helium atom or hydrogen atom with “which component?”] (The 1st clue refers to simplifying the non-interacting helium atom Hamiltonian into 2 hydrogen atom Hamiltonians)

tossups.question: In the United States, Margo St. James founded the group COYOTE to advocate for this industry. A 2019 Allison Schrager book titled for centers of this industry opens with a discussion of Dennis Hof’s GFE service. Regulatory strategies for this industry include neo-abolitionism, which criminalizes buying, but not selling, in this industry. In the Netherlands, this industry is centered on the (*) De Wallen district, where the “window” form of this industry is practiced. This industry is legal in rural Nevada, where participants in this industry undergo mandatory medical testing. This industry's official operations are often contained to "red light districts" and this industry can be driven by sex tourism. For 10 points, name this "oldest profession," the legal variety of which is largely based out of brothels.
tossups.answer: prostitution [or sex work; prompt on pimping; do NOT accept or prompt on "pornography" or related answers]

tossups.question: According to Cassius Dio, a statue in this historical region turned to face Italy after a victory by Segimer and his son. The “miracle of the rain” saved troops in this historical region during a war instigated by Ballomar. Segestes failed to warn of an attack in this historical region; that battle’s remains were found by a man named after this region who was poisoned by a governor of (*) Syria. Lucius Calpurnius Piso killed Caligula’s father, who was named for this historical region. Marcus Aurelius warred with the Marcomanni in this historical region. Three legionary eagles were lost to Arminius in this historical region, leading to Augustus’ outburst at Quinctilius Varus. For 10 points, name this historical region, where the Romans suffered a massive defeat to barbarians in the Teutoburg Forest.
tossups.answer: Germania [or Magna Germania; do not accept or prompt on “Germany”]

tossups.question: A science-fiction author with this surname wrote about Severian, who is exiled from a torturers’ guild, in his series The Book of the New Sun. In one essay, an author with this surname wrote about the “perfect Mary Astor voice” of Felicia after describing “Roquefort cheese morsels rolled in crushed nuts.” An essay by an author with this surname declared race car driver Junior Johnson to be the “Last American Hero,” and his essay (*) “Radical Chic” details a fundraiser hosted by Leonard Bernstein for the Black Panthers. The Mercury 7 and other astronauts are profiled in a book by a man with this surname, who wrote a novel in which the mistress of bond trader Sherman McCoy runs over a black youth. For 10 points, give this surname of the author of The Right Stuff and The Bonfire of the Vanities.
tossups.answer: Wolfe [or Tom Wolfe; or Gene Wolfe; or Thomas Kennerly Wolfe, Jr.; or Gene Rodman Wolfe]

tossups.question: The closed-form solution to a “problem” concerning these entities states that their optimal value is given by the quantity “mu minus r, all over sigma-squared times gamma”. When these entities are derived without transactional costs, they can be approximated graphically by the Merton line. Another theory of these entities seeks to construct an “efficient frontier” of them, which graphically resembles an upward sloping (*) hyperbola. That “modern theory” of these entities was first outlined by Harry Markowitz in a Nobel Prize winning paper on their “Selection”. The expected excess return across one of these entities is divided by the standard deviation to calculate economic risk. For 10 points, give this collection of an investor’s stocks and other assets.
tossups.answer: portfolio [accept Merton’s portfolio problem; prompts on stocks, bonds, or investments with “are collectively known by what term?”](The 1st line refers to Merton’s portfolio problem)

tossups.question: In a play by this author, women try to seduce the protagonist by claiming they forgot their latch-keys. That play by this author takes place before a tour of Africa planned for the egomaniacal actor Garry Essendine. One character exclaims “Sollocks yourself” and breaks a record over the head of her romantic interest in a play by this man. A character created by this author of (*) Present Laughter tampers a car’s brakes in an attempt to kill Charles, but Ruth dies instead. In another play by this author, Elyot and Amanda reunite after they discover they are both honeymooning in the same hotel. Madame Arcati summons the ghost of Charles Condomime’s wife Elvira in a seance in a play by this man. For 10 points, name this playwright who wrote Private Lives and Blithe Spirit.
tossups.answer: Noël Coward [or Sir Noël Peirce Coward]

tossups.question: A series of cartoons titled “The Museum of Horrors” depicted this man as a rabbit in a pot of stew. A tract supporting this man ends with the quotation “I am waiting”. The newspaper La Libre Parole antagonized this man despite evidence of a secret affair between Alessandro Panizzardi and Max von (*) Schwartzkoppen. This man’s sword was publicly broken at the École Militaire. An editorial in L’Aurore supported this man, who was arrested based on a bordereau found in a wastebasket. Ferdinand Esterhazy was found guilty of a crime for which this man was sent to Devil’s Island. For 10 points, name this French-Jewish military officer accused of espionage in a namesake ‘Affair’.
tossups.answer: Alfred Dreyfus

tossups.question: In yeast research, an n-butanol-based reporter system is commonly used to measure the synthesis of this molecule. In plants, glyoxylate and this molecule are acted on by malate synthase. Pantothenic acid is the key input to the biosynthesis of this molecule’s principal component. The carnitine shuttle imports this molecule into the (*) mitochondria. During fasting, increased gluconeogenesis promotes the conversion of this molecule into ketone bodies to be released into the bloodstream. Thiolase produces this molecule during the beta oxidation of fatty acids, and it combines with oxaloacetate in the first step of the TCA cycle. For 10 points, name this molecule produced from the oxidation of pyruvate after glycolysis.
tossups.answer: acetyl-CoA [accept acetyl coenzyme A; prompt on CoA or coenzyme A]

tossups.question: In 2011, this person ruptured his Achilles tendon after chasing a burglar in a hotel. This person appeared dressed in black alongside Jesse Ventura in an appearance on The X-Files. On an episode of Family Guy, Adam West claims this man can be sent back to the Fifth Dimension if his name is said backwards. This man hosted a Pennsylvania governors’ debate in 2018 and the (*) National Geographic Bee until 2013. A fictional version of this man is forced to address “Burt Reynolds” by the name “Turd Ferguson.” Will Ferrell played this person in a series of Saturday Night Live sketches where he is tormented by Sean Connery. In January 2020, this man hosted a series of programs that awarded the title “Greatest of All Time” to Ken Jennings. For 10 points, name this longtime host of Jeopardy!.
tossups.answer: Alex Trebek [or George Alexander Trebek]

tossups.question: This artist spent more than 10 years creating a series of tall, flattened depictions of New York subway passengers against bare backgrounds. An orange-legged woman is wrapped in a striped black cone in this artist’s Aeschylus-inspired Sacrifice of Iphigenia. Arabesques and spirals surround two hourglass-shaped figures in this artist’s surrealist painting Slow Swirl at the Edge of the Sea. After breaking from Surrealism, this artist began his (*) Multiform paintings. This artist created 14 dark palette works for a building that houses a reflecting pool by Philip Johnson and Barnett Newman’s Broken Obelisk. The Seagram Building’s Four Seasons murals are by this namesake of that Chapel in Houston. For 10 points, name this Latvian-born color field painter.
tossups.answer: Mark Rothko [accept Marcus Yakolevich Rothkowitz] Subway Scenes)

bonuses.leadin: 18th century British literature often features an exotic, mysterious setting: America. For 10 points each:
answers: Clarissa, or, the History of a Young Lady
parts: The Female American is an anonymously written novel about a woman who is shipwrecked on an island inhabited by Native Americans, which has drawn comparisons to this Daniel Defoe novel whose title character befriends Friday.
Arabella suggests that the title character of this Samuel Richardson novel move to Pennsylvania until her elopement with Lovelace has “blown over.”
Captain Lismahago returns to England after his adoption by a Native American tribe in this author’s novel The Expedition of Humphry Clinker.

bonuses.leadin: The earliest known ordering system for these institutions was developed in the Pinakes. For 10 points each:
answers: Dewey Decimal Classification [or Dewey Decimal System]
Library of Congress Classification [or LCC; accept any answer indicating the system used by the Library of Congress]
parts: Name these institutions. The first faceted organization system for these institutions is S. R. Ranganathan's Colon Classification.

Perhaps the most famous library classification system was this one, which uses three digit numbers followed by a period and more numbers to classify nonfiction books. This system's namesake had his name stripped from the top honor of the American Library Association for racist and sexist behavior.

This other library classification system was developed by Herbert Putnam and was based on the Cutter Expansive Classification system. This system uses the letters of the alphabet to indicate broad categories followed by a call number.

bonuses.leadin: At least one of these functions may be applied to a vector space with topology, T, if and only if it is a T­1 space that admits a bounded, convex neighborhood of the origin. For 10 points each:
answers: norm [accept normability or other word forms like normalizable; do NOT accept or prompt on seminorm]
Manhattan [accept Manhattan norm or Manhattan plot or Manhattan distance; prompt on New York city]
parts: Name these functions that assign a strictly positive length to each vector in a vector space. These functions are commonly denoted with double vertical lines on each side of the vector they act on.

The aforementioned criterion for determining the normability of a vector space is named for this Russian mathematician. He also names a “zero-one law” describing the tail events of a probability distribution.

The commonly used L1 norm is alternatively named for this geographical location, since it calculates a namesake distance analogous to that of a taxicab driving on rectangular street grids. An unrelated type of scatterplot commonly seen in scientific publications is named for its resemblance to the many skyscrapers in this location.

bonuses.leadin: John Zephaniah Holwell wrote about a prison in this city, describing how 123 people died in one night due to heat exhaustion and cramped conditions. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this city where Siraj ud-Daulah notoriously imprisoned British POW’s.
Siraj ud-Daulah was executed on the orders of this joint-stock corporation, which sent Robert Clive to negotiate and fight with local nawabs for control.

Clive’s partner in establishing the British Raj was this man. This man’s alleged atrocities in India were the subject of a lengthy impeachment trial, where Edmund Burke took four days just to read the charges against him.

bonuses.leadin: In Baddeley and Hitch's multicomponent model of working memory, this structure consists of the articulatory loop and the acoustic store. For 10 points each:
answers: attention [accept word forms; prompt on focus; prompt on awareness]
parts: Name this component of working memory, which stores small amounts of rapidly decaying auditory information.
In the multicomponent model, information from this sense is stored in its spatial sketchpad. Information from this sense is carried by the optic nerve to the occipital lobe.

The multicomponent model explains how the selection in this cognitive process can cause interference when performing the Stroop Test. The Chabris & Simons gorilla suit test demonstrated the blindness of this cognitive process.

bonuses.leadin: This architect’s brick-obsessed “red period” saw him create buildings like the Saynatsalo Town Hall, for which he designed a Renaissance-inspired courtyard with a grass-covered staircase. For 10 points each:
answers: bookstore [prompt on (department) store; do not accept or prompt on library]
parts: Name this Finnish architect. Along with his wife Aino, this architect designed buildings in the “total work of art” style, which would first design a complete building and then add special features to make them more unique.

Aalto used curved brickwork in his design for this University’s Baker House, which was designed to twist in a way that gave each resident a view of the Charles River. Eero Sarinen designed this university’s Kresge auditorium.

Many of Aalto’s later designs were focused on modernizing downtown Helsinki, such as his copper and marble-rich design for one of these retail buildings, found on the same block as his Rautatalo office buildings. The Lello one of these buildings in Portugal is known for its grandiose lighting and staircases.

bonuses.leadin: The single-large or several-small debate concerned the optimal method for preserving a population when one of these regions becomes discontinuous. For 10 points each:
answers: natural habitat [accept habitat size or habitat fragmentation; prompt on niche or range or territory]
parts: Name these ecological regions whose “fragmentation” as a result of human development is a leading cause in the loss of biodiversity.

This three-word term from conservation biology describes the baseline level above which a species threatened by factors like habitat fragmentation is capable of avoiding being drawn into an extinction vortex.

When modeling the minimum viable population, calculations are based on age of maturity, generation time, and this other variable. This quantity’s “potential” value represents the amount of viable oocytes and its “realized” form equals the actual number of offspring.

bonuses.leadin: One of these poems claims “two women together is a work… look at the faces of those who have chosen it” before concluding “I choose to walk here. And to draw this circle.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this set of poems from The Dream of a Common Language inspired by an affair with fellow author Michelle Cliff. The first poem in this set begins “Whenever in this city, screens flicker / with pornography.”

Adrienne Rich, the author of Twenty-One Love Poems, discussed the influence of this earlier American poet in her essay “Vesuvius at Home.” This reclusive “Belle of Amherst” wrote “Because I could not stop for Death.”

Rich claimed that this author’s poetry “is a guide to the ruins, from which we learn what women have lived” in a eulogy from On Lies, Secrets, and Silence. This Confessional poet penned “maybe I am becoming a hermit” in her poem “The Awful Rowing Toward God.”

bonuses.leadin: In 2013, a museum in this state found itself in a controversy over the acquisition of sculptures from antiquity based on its exhibition of the bronze sculpture, Apollo Sauroctonos. For 10 points each:
answers: Ohio [the museums were in Cleveland and Cincinnati, respectively]
satyr [accept faun; accept the Resting Satyr or the House of the Faun]
parts: Name this US state. In 1990, Robert Mapplethorpe was embroiled in a notable obscenity trial based on the exhibition of his photographs at a Contemporary Arts Center in another city from this state.

Despite the controversy, the Cleveland Museum of Art prominently displays their bronze sculpture as an original by this Attic sculptor. This ancient Greek sculptor created Hermes with the Infant Dionysus.

In another work attributed to Praxiteles, one of these figures wears a nebris across their chest and leans on a tree trunk. A sculpture of one of them from the 2nd century BCE provides the name for a preserved residence in Pompeii.

bonuses.leadin: This phrase was chosen after Paul Keyes’ suggestion of “you bet your sweet bippy” was wisely vetoed. For 10 points each:
answers: “sock it to me” [or “sock it to me?” in a Nixon impersonation]
George Wallace [or George Corley Wallace, Jr.]
parts: Name this four-word phrase uttered by Richard Nixon on the show Rowan and Martin’s Laugh-In in an attempt to appeal to younger voters before the 1968 election.
This 1968 presidential candidate was offered a guest spot on Laugh-In, but declined. This man became paralyzed after being shot by Arthur Bremer on a 1972 campaign stop.
Another ploy to win younger voters was this Democrat’s appearance playing the saxophone on The Arsenio Hall Show in a successful campaign to win the 1992 presidential election.

bonuses.leadin: A famous sher by this poet states “I asked my soul, ‘What is Delhi?’ It replied: ‘The world is the body, Delhi its soul.’” For 10 points each:
answers: Mirza Ghalib [or Asad; or Asadullah Khan; prompt on Khan]
Rumi [or Jalāl ad-Dīn Muhammad Balkhī; or Jalāl ad-Dīn Muhammad Balkhī]
parts: Name this poet who wrote hundreds of ghazals in Urdu and served during the last years of the Mughal Empire. He had a rivalry with Muhammad Zauq.
Ghalib wrote in Urdu and this other language, used by Omar Khayyam to write the Rubaiyat. It is the official language of Iran.
This poet and Sufi mystic included many ghazals in his Divan. He used Persian to write the Masnavi.

bonuses.leadin: After Chantico made sacrifices without fasting, she was turned into one of these animals by Tonacatecuchtl For 10 points each:
answers: dog [accept canine or other equivalents; do NOT accept or prompt on "wolf" or other canids]
Mictlantecuhtli [do not accept or prompt on just "Mictlan"]
parts: Name these animals. In another Aztec myth, these animals were created by decapitating Tata and Nene and attaching their heads to their backsides. A god represented as one of these animals is the psychopomp brother of Quetzalcoatl.
This enemy of Quetzalcoatl is credited with creating the first dogs. He replaced his foot with a "smoking mirror" after it was eaten by the crocodile monster, Cipactli.

This deity is the dog sign in Aztec mythology. While attempting to rob this deity, Quetzalcoatl is startled by a group of quail and falls into a ditch. This god later gives Quetzalcoatl a shell without holes, prompting him to use worms to make an instrument.

bonuses.leadin: In On Generation and Corruption, Aristotle outlined the qualities of these entities, to which he added the Aether. For 10 points each:
answers: the classical elements [or four elements; accept earth, water air, fire, and aether in any order]
parts: Name or describe this set of fundamental entities, which the ancient Greeks believed composed all of reality.

This philosopher is the earliest known person to divide the classical elements into earth, water, air, and fire. This philosopher argued that changes in the four elements were driven by the forces of love and strife, which he detailed in the Purifications.
Empedocles legendarily died by throwing himself into Mt. Etna in an attempt to prove his immortality, which was related by this Roman writer, in his book Lives and Opinions of Eminent Philosophers.

bonuses.leadin: P.V. Glob investigated these things, which often bear marks of torture or violence, lending credence to the theory that these things are the result of sacrifices to Nordic gods. For 10 points each:
answers: bog bodies [or bog body; prompt on answers mentioning (mummified/preserved) human corpses/bodies  or mummies]
parts: Name these things, which are often found in their namesake “butter”. A well-preserved example of these things was found at Lindow.
Rupert Bruce-Mitford discovered a “sand body” at this site, which also featured a ship burial for King Raedwald of East Anglia and a famous helmet with neck guards.
Many of the artifacts from Sutton Hoo date back to this metal age. The Hallstatt and La Téne cultures span this age in Europe, which was preceded by the Bronze Age.

bonuses.leadin: This process causes rotational motion in the horizontal arm of a Furuta pendulum but does not apply to the freely rotating vertical arm. For 10 points each:
answers: driving a pendulum [or damped-driven pendulum; accept “oscillator” in place of pendulum; do not accept or prompt on damping alone]
parts: Name this process. A chaotic system partially named for this process has a sinusoidal torque due to it described by the term “A times cosine of omega-sub-D times t”.

A driven pendulum, like a damped pendulum, can have its behavior described by this quantity, which describes how underdamped an oscillator is. When this value equals ½, a simple harmonic oscillator is critically damped.

For a simple pendulum, this quantity can be calculated as the square root of the pendulum’s length over g. This quantity, which is independent of mass and amplitude, is the time it takes for one complete cycle of swings.

bonuses.leadin: This poetic form inspired Welsh composer Karl Jenkins’ five “Death poems”, such as Having Seen the Moon and Farewell. For 10 points each:
answers: I Ching or Book of Changes or Classic of Changes
parts: Name this Japanese poetic form that inspired John Cage to arrange the twelve bars of his piece 40 Drawings by Thoreau into sections of five, seven, and five.

After John Cage was gifted a copy of this text by Christian Wolff, he used it as inspiration for works such as Imaginary Landscape 4 and a namesake piece for David Tudor. Cage frequently used this text to introduce aleatoricism and indeterminacy into his music.

Haikus also feature prominently in the works of contemporary Japanese composer Toshio Hosokawa, such as his Haiku for [this composer]. This Darmstadt School composer included movements like “The Furious Craftsmen” in a work setting multiple poems by Rene Char, The Hammer Without a Master.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about the love lives of German authors. For 10 points each:
answers: the Holocaust [prompt on World War II]
Friedrich Hölderlin [or Johann Christian Friedrich Hölderlin]
parts: Paul Celan’s affair with Ingeborg Bachmann ended when they argued over a negative review of his poem “Death Fugue.” That poem is set during this event, during which the Jewish author Elie Wiesel witnessed his father die.
This author had an affair with Susanne Gontard, who was the mother of the boy he was tutoring, and used her as a model for Diotima in his epistolary novel Hyperion.
Goethe’s marriage proposal was turned down by Ulrike von Levetzow, likely because he was 73 and she was 17. von Levetzow inspired him to write one of these reflective poems named for Marienbad.

bonuses.leadin: An equimolar solution of zinc chloride and hydrochloric acid is used to differentiate primary, secondary, and tertiary forms of this functional group in the Lucas test. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this functional group. Compounds with this functional group are easily identified by the presence of a broad peak around 3300 inverse centimeters in IR spectroscopy.

Primary alcohols are non-reactive in the Lucas test; however, when in the presence of this other compound they readily oxidize into carboxylic acids. This compound consists of chromium trioxide, acetone, and sulfuric acid.
In this reaction, primary alcohols are converted into esters after undergoing stereochemical inversion in the presence of triphenylphosphine and diethyl azodicarboxylate, or DEAD.

bonuses.leadin: This religion follows an "8 word couplet" that was first recorded by Doreen Valiente. For 10 points each:
answers: Wicca [prompt on answers such as neo-Paganism or Witchcraft]
parts: Name this religion, whose namesake Rede is commonly rendered as "An it harm none, do as thou wilt." This neopagan faith was popularized in the 1950s by Gerald Gardner.

The similar phrase "Do what thou wilt shall be the whole of the Law" appears in this man's The Book of the Law. This occultist claimed to be able to hear the supernatural voice of Aiwass during what he termed the "Three Days."
According to Crowley, humanity is currently in an Aeon controlled by a child god symbolized as this falcon headed son of Isis and Osiris.

bonuses.leadin: Joshua Janavel, the “Lion of Rora”, led these people during “Piedmontese Easter”, where they were massacred by Savoyard forces. For 10 points each:
answers: Waldensians [or Vallenses, Waldenses, Valdesi, Vaudois, followers of Peter Waldo; prompt on Poor Men of Lyon]
Louis XIV [prompt on Louis or the Sun King]
parts: Name this Christian sect founded in the 12th century by a wealthy merchant who renounced everything for voluntary poverty.
The Waldensians were massacred by the forces of Victor Amadeus II of Savoy, a nephew of this king. This king revoked the Edict of Nantes from his palace at Versailles.
French religious freedom took a hit during this 1572 event, during which Gaspard de Coligny and other Huguenots were attacked.
